verses.text: Canst thou draw out leviathan with a hook? Or his tongue with a cord \add which\add* thou lettest down?
Canst thou put a hook into his nose? Or bore his jaw through with a thorn?
Will he make many supplications unto thee? Will he speak soft \add words\add* unto thee?
Will he make a covenant with thee? Wilt thou take him for a servant for ever?
Wilt thou play with him as \add with\add* a bird? Or wilt thou bind him for thy maidens?
Shall the companions make a banquet of him? Shall they part him among the merchants?
Canst thou fill his skin with barbed irons? Or his head with fish spears?
Lay thine hand upon him, Remember the battle, do no more.
Behold, the hope of him is in vain: Shall \add not one\add* be cast down even at the sight of him?
None \add is so\add* fierce that dare stir him up: Who then is able to stand before me?
Who hath prevented me, that I should repay \add him?\add* \add Whatsoever is\add* under the whole heaven \add is\add* mine.
I will not conceal his parts, Nor \add his\add* power, nor his comely proportion.
Who can discover the face of his garment? \add Or\add* who can come \add to him\add* with his double bridle?
Who can open the doors of his face? His teeth \add are\add* terrible round about.
\add His\add* scales \add are his\add* pride, Shut up \add together as with\add* a close seal.
One is so near to another, That no air can come between them.
They are joined one to another, They stick together, that they cannot be sundered.
\add By\add* his neesings a light doth shine, And his eyes \add are\add* like the eyelids of the morning.
Out of his mouth go burning lamps, \add And\add* sparks of fire leap out.
Out of his nostrils goeth smoke, As \add out of\add* a seething pot or caldron.
His breath kindleth coals, And a flame goeth out of his mouth.
In his neck remaineth strength, And sorrow is turned into joy before him.
The flakes of his flesh are joined together: They are firm in themselves; they cannot be moved.
His heart is as firm as a stone; Yea, as hard as a piece of the nether \add millstone\add*.
When he raiseth up \add himself\add*, the mighty are afraid: By reason of breakings they purify themselves.
The sword of him that layeth at him cannot hold: The spear, the dart, nor the habergeon.
He esteemeth iron as straw, And \add brass\add* as rotten wood.
The arrow cannot make him flee: Slingstones are turned with him into stubble.
Darts are counted as stubble: He laugheth at the shaking of a spear.
Sharp stones \add are\add* under him: He spreadeth sharp pointed \add things\add* upon the mire.
He maketh the deep to boil like a pot: He maketh the sea like a pot of ointment.
He maketh a path to shine after him; \add One\add* would think the deep to be hoary.
Upon earth there is not his like, Who is made without fear.
He beholdeth all high \add things:\add* He \add is\add* a king over all the children of pride.
